titleStmt.title: Exceeding joyfull newes from Plymouth and Devonshire. Sent in a letter from the deputy lieutenants to the House of Commons, Decemb. 8. wherein is declated [sic] the full proceedings of the cavaleirs against the Parliament forces in the said county, from the 4. of Decemb. to the 9. 1642. Also a full relation of the besieging of Plymouth, by the Lord Grandison, the L. Digby, and Commissarie Wilmot, with 9000. men, and how they were beaten off by the Parliament forces that were within the town, killing about 850. the Lord Digbie being shot through the shoulder, with a musquet bullet.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Exceeding joyfull newes from Plymouth and Devonshire. Sent in a letter from the deputy lieutenants to the House of Commons, Decemb. 8. wherein is declated [sic] the full proceedings of the cavaleirs against the Parliament forces in the said county, from the 4. of Decemb. to the 9. 1642. Also a full relation of the besieging of Plymouth, by the Lord Grandison, the L. Digby, and Commissarie Wilmot, with 9000. men, and how they were beaten off by the Parliament forces that were within the town, killing about 850. the Lord Digbie being shot through the shoulder, with a musquet bullet.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Exceeding Joyfull NEWES FROM Plymouth and Devon≈øhire.

Sent in a Letter from the Deputy Lieutenants to the Hou≈øe of Commons. Decemb. 8. Wherein is declared the full proceedings of the Cavaleirs again≈øt the Parliament Forces in the ≈øaid County, from the 4. of Decemb. to the 9. 1642.

Al≈øo a full Relation of the be≈øieging of Plymouth, by the Lord Grandi≈øon, the L. Digby, and Commi≈ø≈øarie Wilmot, with 9000. men, and how they were beaten off by the parliament forces that were within the Town, killing about 850. the Lord DIGBIE being ≈øhot through the ≈øhoulder, with a musquet bullet.

div.head: THE RELATION OF The great Overthrow given to the Lord M ‚Ä¢ hune, the Lord Grandi≈øon, the Lord Rivers, the Lord Digby, and Commi≈ø≈øary Wilmot.
December the 8, 1642.
By the Renowned and Heroick Champions, the Volunteers of Plymouth, being in number 2000 agein≈øt the aforenamed Per≈øecu ‚Ä¢ ors with 9000.
div.p:
UPon the 7. of this month, the Lord Grandi≈øon advanced from the Kings Army with 3000. hor≈øe and foot, with an
intent to march again≈øt the town of Marlborow in Wilt-≈øhire, but having received a Letter from the L. Mohune, concerning the pre≈øent e≈øtate of Plymouth, he changed his Re≈øolution, and marched towards the ≈øaid Town, to joyn his Forces with the Lord Mohune, the Lord Digby, Commi≈ø≈øary Wilmot, &c.
But by rea≈øon of his long and tedious ‚Ä¢ ll Wedne≈øday night, he lay ≈øhort of the other Forces about 8. miles, on Thur≈øday morning.

But towards 12. of the clock the ≈øame day he got to the Lord Mohune, where he joyned his Forces with him, and the re≈øt of his Confederates, and about three of the clock in the Afternoon they began to move forward toward Plimouth, and about five of the clock they came within one mile of the ≈øaid Town.

But the Forces that were there billeted having information of their comming, prepared a Supper for them, and mounted their Ordnance, ≈øetting their men in battle array, and in a very good po≈øture for their
own defence, and ≈øo ≈øoon as the Cavale ‚Ä¢ rs made their approach neerer the Town, the Plymouth Forces began to welcome them, ≈øending them a great Charger full of black plums, which plums were as bad as poy≈øon to tho≈øe that ta≈øted of them; for they made ≈øuch a ≈ølanghter among≈øt the Kings Army, that many hundreds of them lay dead before the Town Walls.

The Lord Digby and Commi≈ø≈øary Wilmot ≈øeeing this, with much futy and violence they adventured up with their Forces, and gave a de≈øperate charge again≈øt the Parliament-Forces, but did very little execution, and although they were fix to one, yet our men gave them the foyl, obtaining a happy Victory, and putting neer upon 9. hundred and fifty to the ≈øword, with the lo≈ø≈øe of one hundred and twenty men, be≈øides the Lord Digby is dangerou≈øly wounded, being ≈øhot through the ≈øhoulder with a bullet.

The Lord Mohune and the re≈øt of the Cavaleers are retreated 20. miles from Plymouth, and it is very probable hee will have
but little ≈øtomack to come thither againe, by rea≈øon they ta≈øted of ≈øuch hard fare; yet if they do come to make another attempt, the plymouth forces are re≈øolved to prelent unto them the like plums which they ta≈øted of before.

The like proceedings hath bin in Che≈øhire, between the Lord Rivers and his Adherents, again≈øt the well-affected party of that County, as it was declared in a Letter to Sir William Brewerton, a member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, intimating that the L. Rivers having rai≈øed an Army of Papi≈øts and di≈øaffected prote≈øtants is very active in that County to put in execution the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array, and plunders and pillages all tho≈øe that refu≈øe to yeeld obedience to his illegall Commands.

And therfore the County de≈øires, that the Parliament will ≈øpeedily take order for ≈øending ≈øome Commanders unto them, for a great part of that County ≈øtands very well affected to the Parliament, and are re≈øolved to ≈øpend their lives and fortunes in this cau≈øe.

Whereupon the Parliament have ordained that ≈øome ≈øpeedy aid ≈øhall be ≈øent unto them, and that they ≈øhall a≈ø≈øociate them≈øelues together, to defend them≈øelves from tyranny and oppre≈ø≈øion, and to maintain the peace of that County again≈øt all that did oppo≈øe them.

And it is credibly informed, that upon Tue≈øday la≈øt there was a generall meeting of the well-affected Prote≈øtants, who ≈øtood in oppo≈øition again≈øt the Lord Rivers and his Cavaleers, and at the la≈øt gave them a Charge, killing about 40. of his men.

Whereupon the L. Rivers mu≈øtred his Forces together, placing them in battle array, and drawing them up to a head, and at the la≈øt wheeling about, and obtaining the wind, they charged again≈øt the Parliament Forces, but after one hours fight they were forced to retreat, by rea≈øon that two of our Troops of hor≈øe broke in upon the L. Rivers left wing, breaking their Rankes and files, and bringing them to a mo≈øt confu≈øed Order, killing 2. or 300, and putting the re≈øt to flight.

Upon Friday la≈øt, there was Letters came to the Hou≈øe of Commons, directed to Mr. Speaker, out of Devon≈øhire, informing the hou≈øe of the true e≈øtate of things in that County, and that the Cavaleers do exceedingly plunder and ≈øpoyl that County, and that they are marching from Tave≈øtack toward Plymouth, and do threaten that Town but the Committee for the Militia being there, they have gotten ≈øome new forces into the Town, and are in a good po≈øture of defence.

Al≈øo the Deputy Lieutenants at Exce≈øter have rai≈øed three Regiments of the Trayned Bands of the adjacent Counties, and are re≈øolved to aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øt Plymouth, The Parliament hath al≈øo made the E. of Stamford Generall of South-Wales, and his Son the young Lord Grey, Generall of Liece≈øter ≈øhire, Darby-≈øhire, and Lincoln-≈øhire.

p.hi: The Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parl. do declare, that all ≈øouldiers that do commit any offence contrary to their Orders ≈øhall be brought to condigne puni≈øhment, and that they may be ≈øeverely proceeded again≈øt according to Law.
